elements.recognition_pattern: Centered text at the top of the page, appearing on all pages except the first. The font is smaller than the document title.
examples: DEMONSTRATE–SEARCH–PREDICT: Composing retrieval and language models

elements.recognition_pattern: Text located at the bottom-left of the first page, separated from the main content by a thin horizontal line. May be prefixed with a symbol like '*'.
Large, bold, centered text at the top of the first page. It is the most prominent textual element on the page.
examples: DEMONSTRATE–SEARCH–PREDICT: Composing retrieval and language models for knowledge-intensive NLP

elements.recognition_pattern: A heading for a major part of the paper. It is bold, centered (for Abstract, Acknowledgements) or left-aligned (for numbered sections), and may be numbered with an integer followed by a period (e.g., '1. '). The text is typically in all-caps or title case.
The heading 'References', which is bold, left-aligned, and not numbered. It introduces the list of citations at the end of the paper.
A heading prefixed with a two-part number (e.g., '2.1. '). The text is bold and in title case.
An unnumbered heading. The text is bold, italic, and in title case.

notes: The paper uses a two-column layout. The first page includes a prominent vertical text block on the left with arXiv metadata ('arXiv:2212.14024v2...'). The authors and their affiliations are listed below the title but are not considered a structural heading. Sections 'Acknowledgements' and 'References' share formatting with numbered sections but are not numbered themselves. There are code blocks formatted with a monospaced font interspersed in the text.
